there is no "successor" field for this template
use of boldface for first mention of the acronym analogous to the "Compact Disc" article
see the first lines in the editing mask: "This product is called "Blu-ray Disc". Not "Blu-Ray" or "Blue-Ray" [...] Please remember to use the name above and not the incorrect variations [...]"
/* BD+ */ - Attempt #2 to correct patent link. Sorry again.
/* BD+ */ - Add country code to patent # so the link works. Apologies for so many edits in a row.
/* BD+ */ - Added citations, some additional information about circumvention software. The cited patent is not "for" BD+ but "refers" to BD+
/* Region codes */ - It isn't an "attempt" when it's successful
/* Region codes */ - Wording cleanup and factual correction (region coding is never verified by the computer OS)

corrected "enhanced definition betamax" to extended definition beta (ED Beta)
/* Application format */ BDMV recording was defined in 2006 for BD-RE and BD-R
/* Filesystem */ In the first BD-RE specification (defined in 2002), the '''BDFS''' (Blu-ray Disc File System) was used.; added references
/* Application format */ added BDMV Recording specification
/* Software standards */ added File and folder structure of BD-ROM
/* Container Format */ Usage of BDMV disc format was later defined also for BD-RE and BD-R.
Undid revision 366756793 by [[Special:Contributions/213.77.7.137|213.77.7.137]] ([[User talk:213.77.7.137|talk]]): see the pertinent BDA white paper
If you write 50 fps then resulution is 1920×540 (interlaced video). If you want to 1920×1080 then frame rate is 25 per second. When you use 1920x1080/50 fps, it sugges beter quality than progresive.

/* Laser and optics */ No, Blu-ray Disc tech uses GaN lasers, not InGaN.
sorry, I was logged out: it was me who made the previous changes
as per official specs; to user 86.182.66.217: please see my talk page
PLEASE READ the fourth line in the editing mask – or the FIRST line of the article ITSELF, for that matter; and look at the damned logo: see the "D"?
My confusion - I confused H.264 with AVCHD
H.264 is prohibited from Blu-ray (but allowed on Blu-ray format DVDs)
"disc" is not a proper noun so should not be capitalised.
Spelling – But what is this footnote about anyway? Doesn't seem to make ANY sense.
/* Hard-coating technology */ Clarification: the scratch-resistant layer is optional. However, there is a requirement on the scratch-resistance of the disk, regardless of the method used to meet it.
/* End of the format war and future prospects */ Last paragraph consolidation
